name: Aluminium 2014
desc: High-strength Al-Cu alloy; good for machined parts and aerospace-style plate. Not the best for corrosion resistance.

name: Aluminium 2024
desc: High-strength aerospace Al-Cu alloy; great for structural parts. Lower corrosion resistance than 6xxx series.

name: Aluminium 6061
desc: General-purpose aluminium for CNC and fabrication; widely available, weldable, and reliable.

name: Aluminium 6082
desc: Common EU structural aluminium; a go-to for general machining and fabrication with good strength.

name: Aluminium 7075
desc: Very high-strength aluminium; great for highly loaded parts and tooling. Less weldable and can be notch-sensitive.

name: Aluminium 1050
desc: Commercially pure aluminium; soft and very formable. Used for sheet work, covers, and general fabrication.

name: Aluminium 5083
desc: Marine-grade aluminium; excellent corrosion resistance and weldability. Often used in plate.

name: Aluminium 5754
desc: Fabrication-friendly aluminium; good corrosion resistance for sheet/plate parts and welded assemblies.

name: Aluminium MIC-6 (Cast Tooling Plate)
desc: Cast, stress-relieved tooling plate; very flat and stable. Ideal for fixtures, plates, and machine components.

name: Aluminium A356 (Cast)
desc: Common cast aluminium alloy; good castability and stability. Often used for housings and cast components.

name: Aluminium 6063
desc: Extrusion alloy; common for profiles, rails, and light structural parts. Typically better finish than 6061.

name: Aluminium 6081
desc: Less common designation; sometimes used in older specs/supply chains. Treat as 6082-family structural aluminium.

name: Aluminium 7050
desc: Aerospace plate alloy; high strength with improved stress-corrosion resistance vs 7075.

name: Copper ETP
desc: Electrolytic tough pitch copper; excellent electrical/thermal conductivity. Soft and can be gummy to machine.

name: Copper OFHC
desc: Oxygen-free high-conductivity copper; used for vacuum/electrical/thermal parts. Very soft and can smear when cutting.

name: Beryllium Copper
desc: High-strength copper alloy; great for springs, contacts, and tooling. Often heat-treated; dust control matters when machining.

name: Brass CW505L
desc: Formable brass for sheet/presswork; good corrosion resistance and appearance. Not the best for heavy wear parts.

name: Brass CW614N (Free Cutting)
desc: Free-machining brass; excellent for turned parts and threads. Not ideal for high-load sliding wear.

name: Brass CZ121
desc: UK designation for free-cutting brass; used for turned components, fittings, and fasteners.

name: Phosphor Bronze
desc: Wear-resistant bronze; good fatigue life for springs and excellent sliding for bushes.

name: Bronze SAE 660
desc: Classic bearing bronze; dependable for bushes, thrust washers, and wear parts with good embedability.

name: Aluminium Bronze (C95400)
desc: High-strength bronze; good wear and corrosion resistance. Used in marine, heavy-duty bushes, and load parts.

name: Nickel 200
desc: Commercially pure nickel; strong chemical resistance and good electrical properties. Not a high-strength alloy.

name: Monel 400
desc: Nickel-copper alloy for marine/chemical service; corrosion resistant and tough. Can work-harden during machining.

name: Inconel 718
desc: Nickel superalloy for high temperature strength; aerospace/turbine-grade. Difficult machining; work-hardens.

name: Titanium 6Al-4V
desc: Grade 5 titanium; high strength-to-weight and low expansion. Tough to machine and prone to spring-back.

name: Titanium Grade 2 (CP)
desc: Commercially pure titanium; excellent corrosion resistance and good formability. Lower strength than Grade 5.

name: ABS
desc: General engineering plastic; easy to machine and tough. High expansion and can creep under load.

name: Acetal Copolymer (POM-C)
desc: Low-friction plastic; stable and machinable. Great for bushes, sliders, and general precision plastic parts.

name: Delrin (Acetal Homopolymer, POM-H)
desc: Stiffer acetal with excellent machinability; good for precise low-friction parts. Slightly different properties vs POM-C by supplier.

name: Delrin AF (PTFE-Filled)
desc: PTFE-filled acetal; lower friction and improved wear for sliding parts. Strength can be slightly reduced vs unfilled.

name: Nylon 6/6
desc: Tough and impact resistant; common for wear parts. Moisture absorption changes size and properties.

name: PEEK (Unfilled)
desc: High-performance polymer; heat resistant and strong. Good for precision parts where plastics must behave more like metals.

name: PEEK Bearing Grade
desc: Filled PEEK for wear; improved sliding performance with lower expansion than unfilled. Used for bushes and seals.

name: PEEK CF30 (30% Carbon-Filled)
desc: Carbon-filled PEEK; very low expansion and high stiffness. Excellent for precision polymer components.

name: PEEK GF30 (30% Glass-Filled)
desc: Glass-filled PEEK; low expansion and stiff. Can be more abrasive to mating surfaces than unfilled.

name: PTFE (Teflon)
desc: Extremely low friction and chemically resistant. Very high expansion and can cold-flow/creep under load.

name: HDPE
desc: Common, easy-fabrication plastic; tough and chemical resistant. High expansion and lower stiffness.

name: UHMW-PE
desc: Very tough wear plastic; excellent sliding/impact. Very high expansion and difficult to hold tight tolerances.

name: Polycarbonate (PC)
desc: Tough, impact resistant, often clear. Moderate-high expansion and can stress crack with some chemicals.

name: PVC (Rigid)
desc: Rigid PVC for panels, ducting, and fabricated parts. Moderate expansion; chemical resistant but lower temperature capability.

name: Polypropylene (PP)
desc: Light, chemical-resistant fabrication plastic. High expansion and relatively flexible.

name: PET
desc: Stable polyester plastic; good dimensional stability for a commodity polymer. Moderate expansion.

name: Phenolic (Bakelite)
desc: Laminated resin used for fixtures and electrical insulation; relatively stable for a polymer. Can be brittle.

name: Soda-lime Glass
desc: Common glass for general use; moderate expansion and not great for thermal shock.

name: Borosilicate Glass
desc: Low-expansion glass with good thermal shock resistance; labware and instrument parts.

name: Fused Silica
desc: Ultra-low expansion glass; excellent for optics and metrology where stability matters most.

name: Alumina (96%)
desc: Common technical ceramic; stiff and wear resistant. Used for fixtures, insulators, and wear components.

name: Zirconia
desc: Very tough ceramic for a ceramic; used for wear parts, probes, and impact-prone applications.

name: Silicon Carbide
desc: Very stiff, wear resistant ceramic; low expansion. Used for precision, wear, and high-stiffness parts.

name: Tungsten Carbide
desc: Cutting tool and wear material; very stiff with low expansion. Great for gauges, wear pads, and tooling.

name: Titanium Carbide (TiC)
desc: Hard carbide ceramic; used in cutting and wear applications. Higher expansion than tungsten carbide.

name: Boron Carbide (B4C)
desc: Extremely hard ceramic; wear and abrasive service. Often used where weight and hardness matter.

name: Graphite — Polycrystalline (General/Average)
desc: Graphite average value when orientation is unknown; useful for general estimating and mixed-grain parts.

name: Graphite — Parallel / In-plane
desc: Along basal planes; lowest expansion direction. Relevant for plates or layups with known orientation.

name: Graphite — Perpendicular / Through-thickness
desc: Normal to basal planes; higher expansion direction. Relevant for thickness growth in graphite plates.

name: Carbon Fibre Composite (Generic)
desc: Direction-averaged CFRP; expansion varies strongly by fibre orientation and layup. Use as a rough estimate.

name: Grey Cast Iron (EN-GJL-250)
desc: Machine bases and plates; excellent vibration damping and good thermal stability. Great for fixtures and machine parts.

name: Ductile Cast Iron (EN-GJS-500)
desc: Nodular iron; tougher than grey iron with similar expansion. Used for stronger cast components.

name: Stainless 17-4 PH
desc: Precipitation-hardening stainless; high strength with moderate expansion (condition dependent). Used for shafts and high-strength parts.

name: Stainless 303
desc: Free-machining austenitic stainless; great for turned parts. Reduced corrosion resistance vs 304/316.

name: Stainless 304
desc: General-purpose austenitic stainless; widely used for fabricated and machined parts with good corrosion resistance.

name: Stainless 316
desc: Marine/chemical austenitic stainless; better corrosion resistance than 304. Common for coastal/outdoor use.

name: Stainless Duplex 2205
desc: Duplex stainless; high strength and strong chloride resistance. Often used in marine and process environments.

name: Stainless 410
desc: Martensitic stainless; hardenable with lower expansion. Used for wear parts and moderate corrosion environments.

name: Stainless 420
desc: Hardenable martensitic stainless; good for knives, tools, and wear parts. Better hardness potential than 410.

name: Stainless 431
desc: High-strength martensitic stainless; used for shafts and high-load components. Expansion lower than austenitic grades.

name: Stainless 904L
desc: Highly alloyed stainless for aggressive chemical environments; expensive but excellent corrosion resistance.

name: Steel 1020
desc: Low carbon steel; general engineering and fabrication. Good baseline for mild steel expansion.

name: Steel 1018
desc: Low carbon steel; common bar stock for machined parts. Good machinability and weldability.

name: Steel EN1A / 12L14
desc: Free-machining mild steel; excellent for turned parts. Lower strength and weldability can be limited by leaded grades.

name: Steel S235
desc: EU structural mild steel; common in frames and fabricated structures. Reliable general-purpose grade.

name: Steel S355
desc: Higher strength EU structural steel; used for heavier-duty frames and structures with similar expansion to S235.

name: Steel 4140 / EN8
desc: Medium alloy steel for shafts and gears; strong and heat-treatable. Very common engineering choice.

name: Steel 4340 / EN24T
desc: High-strength alloy steel; used for highly loaded shafts/gears and aerospace-style parts. Tough and heat-treatable.

name: Steel A2
desc: Air-hardening tool steel; stable in heat treatment. Good for dies, punches, and precision tooling.

name: Steel D2
desc: High-wear tool steel; excellent abrasion resistance for dies and punches. Can be more brittle than A2.

name: Steel P20
desc: Pre-hardened mould steel; used for plastic injection moulds and tooling plates. Machines well in pre-hard state.

name: Invar 36
desc: Ultra-low expansion Fe-Ni alloy; used for metrology, fixtures, and precision references. Poor machinability and expensive.

name: Tool Steel H13
desc: Hot-work tool steel; good toughness at temperature. Used for forging dies, hot tooling, and die-casting components.

name: Steel EN3 / 070M20
desc: Mild/medium carbon steel; general engineering and fabrication. Common workshop material.

name: Steel EN19 / 4140 QT
desc: Quenched & tempered alloy steel; strong and reliable for shafts/gears. A staple for high-load machined parts.

name: Steel EN36A
desc: Case-hardening steel; used for gears and wear surfaces with a tough core. Useful where hard skin + tough inside is needed.

name: Steel O1 Tool Steel
desc: Oil-hardening tool steel; good for cutters, punches, and general tooling. Simple heat treat and widely used.

name: PLA
desc: Common 3D printing plastic; stiff and easy to print. Can creep with heat and has moderate expansion.

name: PET-G
desc: Tough 3D printing plastic; good layer adhesion and lower warp. Moderate expansion.

name: ABS
desc: 3D printing ABS; tough and heat resistant vs PLA, but warps more. High expansion and needs stable printing conditions.

name: ASA
desc: UV-stable ABS-like filament; good for outdoor parts. High expansion and can warp like ABS but often prints cleaner.

name: Nylon (3D Printing Grade)
desc: Tough, impact-resistant filament; good wear properties. Moisture sensitive and high expansion.

name: TPU
desc: Flexible filament; great for grips, bumpers, and dampers. High expansion and tolerance control is harder.

name: CF-Filled PLA / PET-G (Generic)
desc: Carbon-filled filament; stiffer with lower expansion than unfilled. Properties vary widely by brand and fill percentage.
